content.question:
Refer to figure.
If you want to fly a magnetic heading of 300°, what compass heading should the aircraft steer and what is the compass deviation?

key_points: When a magnetic needle is influenced only by the Earth’s magnetic field, it points to magnetic north

But, if the compass is installed in an aircraft, the Earth's magnetic field will be distorted by the metal and the electrical equipment around it and the needle now deviates slightly from magnetic north, indicating a direction of 000°, known as compass north
Deviation varies with magnetic latitude, aircraft heading and changes in aircraft electronic equipment
learning.explanation: When a magnetic needle is influenced only by the Earth’s magnetic field, it points to magnetic north. But, if the compass is installed in an aircraft, the Earth's magnetic field will be distorted by the metal and the electrical equipment around it and the needle now deviates slightly from magnetic north, indicating a direction of 000°, known as compass north. Deviation varies with magnetic latitude, aircraft heading and changes in aircraft electronic equipment. The difference between the direction of magnetic north and that of compass north is called "deviation". Deviation is measured in degrees and is described as "East" (+) or "West" (-). To determine whether the deviation should be added or subtracted, use the rhyme: “Deviation East - Compass Least“ “Deviation West - Compass Best“ According to the figure’s compass deviation card, to fly a magnetic heading of 300°, the aircraft must steer to a compass heading of 298°. And since the compass heading is 2° less than the magnetic heading, then the deviation is 2°E.

content.question: An aircraft departs point A, intending to fly direct to point B, 140 NM away. After flying 18 minutes or 41 NM, the aircraft is 7 NM left of track.To regain the intended track in an equal amount of time, the heading of the aircraft must be changed:

key_points: It is normal during flight that the track over the ground is different from the desired trajectory defined during planning
If this is the case, some heading corrections should be made so that we can return to the track
The track you want to fly is the planned track, and the track you actually make over the ground is the track made good
learning.explanation: It is normal during flight that the track over the ground is different from the desired trajectory defined during planning. If this is the case, some heading corrections should be made so that we can return to the track. The track you want to fly is the planned track, and the track you actually make over the ground is the track made good. The difference between them is called track error (TE). The angle at which we want to close to come back to the planned track is the closing angle (CA). The CA will depend how much further we want to rejoin the planned track. The 1 in 60 rule can be used to calculate the TE and the CA. TE = (distance off-track/planned track distance flown) x 60 TE = (7/41) x 60 = 10º The same 1 in 60 rule can be applied to calculate the CA. CA = (distance off-track/distance at which we want to rejoin track) x 60 CA = (7/41) x 60 = 10º With both TE and CA, we can determine by how much heading change we should apply to regain track: Heading change = TE + CA = 10º + 10º = 20º R The aircraft is left off-track, the aircraft must fly right to regain track.

content.question: An aircraft's compass heading is 004°. The deviation card indicates 1°W on northerly headings and the variation is 5°W. What is the aircraft's true heading?

key_points: MAGNETIC VARIATION The earth behaves as though a huge permanent magnet were situated near the centre producing a magnetic field over the surface

The poles of this hypothetical earth-magnet do not lie on the earth’s spin axis, this lack of symmetry giving rise to magnetic variation - the angular difference between the True North (TN) and the Magnetic North (MN)

Variation is designated west or east depending on whether the magnetic pole lies to the west or to the east of true north: - If the Magnetic North is west of the True North, westerly variation, the magnetic direction will have a higher angular value than the true direction
learning.explanation: MAGNETIC VARIATION The earth behaves as though a huge permanent magnet were situated near the centre producing a magnetic field over the surface. The poles of this hypothetical earth-magnet do not lie on the earth’s spin axis, this lack of symmetry giving rise to magnetic variation - the angular difference between the True North (TN) and the Magnetic North (MN). Variation is designated west or east depending on whether the magnetic pole lies to the west or to the east of true north: - If the Magnetic North is west of the True North, westerly variation, the magnetic direction will have a higher angular value than the true direction. - If the Magnetic North is east of the True North, easterly variation, the magnetic direction will have a lower angular value than the true direction. Variation (-) West – Magnetic Best Variation (+) East – Magnetic Least COMPASS DEVIATION Magnetic material and electrical circuits surround the flight deck that influence the Earth’s magnetic field and cause the compass needle to deflect away from the local magnetic meridian. This is known as compass deviation and can result in deviation either east or west of magnetic north by an amount, which depends on the aeroplane’s heading and latitude. Deviation (-) West – Compass Best Deviation (+) East – Compass Least Any deviation can be analysed and resolved into components acting along the aeroplane’s major axes. The causes of the deviation are analysed and corrected for by carrying out a compass swing, although some residual deviation remains, and recording them on a deviation card. To obtain a True Heading from the Compass Heading: Use the acronym C-D-M-V-T, and replace the values you are given in the question: From left to right, magnetic deviation W is subtracted from Compass Heading to get Magnetic Heading and magnetic variation E is added to Compass Heading to get Magnetic Heading. From left to right, magnetic variation W is subtracted from Magnetic Heading to get True Heading and magnetic variation E is added to Magnetic Heading to get True Heading: Compass Heading (C) Deviation (D) Magnetic Heading (M) Variation (V) True Heading (T) 004º 001ºW 003º 5ºW 358º

content.question:
Find the actual track of the aircraft, given:
Planned track: 157°(T),
Pre-flight wind correction angle calculation: 8° left,
Actual in-flight drift: 10° right.

key_points: Drift is the angle from the a/c’s heading to the actual track, as a result of the wind direction and speed
Wind correction angle (WCA) is the correction that has to be made to counteract for the drift, because of the wind, so as to follow the desired track
WCA is of equal amount with the drift, but it has opposite direction
learning.explanation: Drift is the angle from the a/c’s heading to the actual track, as a result of the wind direction and speed. Wind correction angle (WCA) is the correction that has to be made to counteract for the drift, because of the wind, so as to follow the desired track. WCA is of equal amount with the drift, but it has opposite direction. For example, when drift is 4oL, the WCA that must be made is 4oR. At this question, you have to distinguish the pre-flight with the actual data. The pre-flight WCA is 8oL, because the pilot was expecting a drift of 8oR due to the wind. But the actual drift is not 8oR as expected, but it is 2o more to the right, 10o R. Therefore, the actual track of the a/c will be also 2o more to the right in comparison with the planned track. So, 157o+2o= 159oT.

content.question: Which statement is correct regarding the magnetic variation?

options.A: The charted values of magnetic variation on Earth normally change annually due to the magnetic pole movement causing numerical values at all locations to increase or decrease.
options.B: The charted values of magnetic variation on Earth normally change annually due to magnetic pole movement causing numerical values at all locations to increase.
options.C: The charted values of magnetic variation on Earth normally change annually due to an increasing field strength causing numerical values at all locations to increase.
options.D: The charted values of magnetic variation on Earth normally change annually due to a reducing field strength causing numerical values at all locations to decrease.

key_points: The poles of the Earth's magnetic field are close to the geographic poles, which lie on the axis of the Earth's rotation, but not coincident, so that a compass pointing to magnetic north will not point exactly at the geographic north pole
The angle between the true meridian and the magnetic meridian, or the difference between the true north and the magnetic north, is called variation and varies between 180o and zero
Due to the dynamic nature of the earth’s interior, the magnetic field is constantly changing
learning.explanation: The poles of the Earth's magnetic field are close to the geographic poles, which lie on the axis of the Earth's rotation, but not coincident, so that a compass pointing to magnetic north will not point exactly at the geographic north pole. The angle between the true meridian and the magnetic meridian, or the difference between the true north and the magnetic north, is called variation and varies between 180o and zero. Due to the dynamic nature of the earth’s interior, the magnetic field is constantly changing. Since, the Earth's magnetic pole is slowly moving around, the variation increases or decreases annually and therefore the date of any map showing variation is important, because if it is an old map, its variations will be incorrect. The pilots should always fly with the most up-to-date chart for flight safety reasons. If the chart is republished at frequent intervals, the variation should be comparatively recent as well.

content.question:
Consider the following factors that determine the accuracy of a DR position:
1. The flight time since the last position update.
2. The accuracy of the forecasted wind.
3. The accuracy of the TAS.
4. The accuracy of the steered heading.
Using the list above which of the following contains the most complete answer?

key_points: In navigation, dead reckoning is the process of calculating one's current position by using a previously determined position, or fix, and advancing that position based upon known or estimated speeds over elapsed time and course
The corresponding term in biology, used to describe the processes by which animals update their estimates of position or heading, is path integration
Dead reckoning is subject to cumulative errors
learning.explanation: In navigation, dead reckoning is the process of calculating one's current position by using a previously determined position, or fix, and advancing that position based upon known or estimated speeds over elapsed time and course. The corresponding term in biology, used to describe the processes by which animals update their estimates of position or heading, is path integration. Dead reckoning is subject to cumulative errors. Advances in navigational aids that give accurate information on position, in particular satellite navigation using the Global Positioning System, have made simple dead reckoning by humans obsolete for most purposes. However, inertial navigation systems, which provide very accurate directional information, use dead reckoning and are very widely applied. By analogy with their navigational use, the words dead reckoning are also used to mean the process of estimating the value of any variable quantity by using an earlier value and adding whatever changes have occurred in the meantime. Often, this usage implies that the changes are not known accurately. The earlier value and the changes may be measured or calculated quantities. Accuracy of DR depends on many factors: 1- Time since last position update. 2- Meteorological accuracy of the forecasted wind. 3- Accuracy of heading and speed (GS) flown. 4- Knowledge of pilots in Navigation.

content.question: You are flying from point A to point B, a distance of 75 NM, on a heading of 288°. After 45 NM you have diverged 4° right off track. What heading correction should be made to reach position B?

key_points: Two heading corrections must be made to reach position B: The aircraft have diverged 4o right off track, so the first correction must be a left turn by the same amount of degrees, 4o, to parallel with the desired track, following a heading of: 288° - 4o = 284°
But, after this correction the aircraft will be just following the desired track in parallel and will never reach position B
The distance-off track is required for the second correction, which is given by the 1:60 rule based formula: (Distance off track / Miles travelled) = (Degrees to parallel / 60)
learning.explanation: Two heading corrections must be made to reach position B: The aircraft have diverged 4o right off track, so the first correction must be a left turn by the same amount of degrees, 4o, to parallel with the desired track, following a heading of: 288° - 4o = 284°. But, after this correction the aircraft will be just following the desired track in parallel and will never reach position B. The distance-off track is required for the second correction, which is given by the 1:60 rule based formula: (Distance off track / Miles travelled) = (Degrees to parallel / 60). Solving for Distance off track we get: Distance off track = Degrees to parallel x Miles travelled / 60 = 4o x 45 NM / 60 = 3 NM. The second correction that must be so as to intercept position B, is given by the 1:60 rule based formula: (Distance off track / Miles to go) = (Degrees to intercept / 60). Solving for Degrees to intercept we get: Degrees to intercept = (Distance off track x 60) / Miles to go = (3 NM x 60) / (75 NM - 45 NM) = 6o left. Thus, the total correction that must be made is: 4o left + 6o left = 10o Left onto 288o - 10o = 278o heading.

An aircraft flies over a small lake which is located some degrees to the left of the planned track. Given the following information and using the 1 in 60 rule, what is the drift angle of this aircraft (rounded to the nearest whole degree)?

Tailwind component: 15 kt
Flight time from previous waypoint: 11 min
Off-track distance between the lake and the track: 2.4 NM

key_points: The aircraft flying with a TAS of 100 kt and experiencing a tailwind of 15 kt, will have a Groundspeed of: TAS + Tailwind component = 100 kt + 15 kt = 115 kt
The 1:60 rule states that: "For each degree of drift angle you will be one NM off-track having travelled 60 NM along track"
If you are only 20 NM along track, every one degree of drift angle relates to one third of a NM
learning.explanation: The aircraft flying with a TAS of 100 kt and experiencing a tailwind of 15 kt, will have a Groundspeed of: TAS + Tailwind component = 100 kt + 15 kt = 115 kt. The 1:60 rule states that: "For each degree of drift angle you will be one NM off-track having travelled 60 NM along track". If you are only 20 NM along track, every one degree of drift angle relates to one third of a NM. If so, 2 NM off-track must equate to a 6º drift angle and 3 NM off-track must equate to a 9º drift angle. For this question, the aircraft experiences the 2.4 NM off-track distance between the lake and the track, 11 minutes from the previous waypoint. So, the distance from the previous waypoint until the aircraft flies above the small lake is: Distance = GS x Flight time = 115 kt x 11/60 hr = 21 NM. Applying the 1:60 rule, an aircraft which is off-track 2.4 NM after 60 NM, will have a drift angle of 2.4º. Thus, after 21 NM, the aircraft will have a drift angle of: 2.4º x 2.86 (60/21)= 7º (rounded).

content.question: An aircraft is climbing to FL300 in ISA conditions with a constant Mach of 0.60. At the initiation of the climb, the aircraft instruments indicate a TAS of 365 kt and a CAS of 264 kt. While climbing, the pilot checks again the speeds after some time. What will be the indications?

options.B: TAS at 371 kt and CAS at 286 kt.

options.D: TAS at 356 kt and CAS at 233 kt.

key_points: No calculations are required for this question, because it asks for TAS and CAS “at some point during climb” and not at a specific altitude during climb
A usefool tool in determining the changing relationship between EAS, CAS, TAS and Mach in climbs and descents, below the tropopause, is the ECTM graphs
CAS can be considered to be identical to IAS
learning.explanation: No calculations are required for this question, because it asks for TAS and CAS “at some point during climb” and not at a specific altitude during climb. A usefool tool in determining the changing relationship between EAS, CAS, TAS and Mach in climbs and descents, below the tropopause, is the ECTM graphs. CAS can be considered to be identical to IAS. The ECTM graphs are used to determine what happens to the other three speeds when climbing or descending, whilst holding one speed constant, by drawing initially the parameter that is to be held constant as a vertical line and drawing, later, connecting lines to the remaining letters. The lines are always in the sequence "ECTM", in the standard atmosphere and the speed held constant is drawn vertically. During climb with a constant Mach number, both TAS and CAS decrease. Thus, since at the beginning of the descent the instruments' cross-check shows a CAS of 264 kt and a TAS of 365 kt, at a higher altitude during the climb, both TAS and CAS speeds are expected to be lower. Therefore, the option that gives both a CAS less than 264 kt and a TAS less than 365 kt is TAS at 356 kt and CAS at 233 kt.

content.question: An aircraft flies from A to B, the ground distance is 78 NM. After 48 NM the pilot notices a cross-track error angle of 4° to the right. In order to directly reach point B, by using the “1 in-60” rule, the pilot should change the heading to the left by...

key_points: By altering the heading towards the original track (to the left) by 4°, the aircraft will fly parallel to the original track
To re-join the original track at A, we must find the track correction to reach B
For that, we need to find the distance off-track first
learning.explanation: By altering the heading towards the original track (to the left) by 4°, the aircraft will fly parallel to the original track. To re-join the original track at A, we must find the track correction to reach B. For that, we need to find the distance off-track first. We have been given the Track Angle Error (TKE) of 4° to the right. We can determine the distance off track by applying the following formula: TKE = (distance off track × 60) ÷ distance along track 4° = (distance off track × 60) ÷ 48 distance off track = (4° x 48) ÷ 60 = 3 NM The correction to reach B will be: TKE = (distance off track × 60) ÷ distance to go TKE = (3 × 60) ÷ 30 TKE = 6° ⇒ Turning 4° to the left will lead us to fly parallel to the original track. Turning an extra 6° to the left will direct us to "B". 4° + 6° = 10° to the left to go direct to "B".

With the introduction of modern navigational techniques such as GPS and conventional radio navigational aids, this may seem outdated technique. Accuracy of DR depends on: Time elapsed since last fix; Accuracy of the wind velocity used; Accuracy of headings and airspeeds; Skill and knowledge of the pilot. Reasons for why we continue to teach Dead Reckoning: 1. Creation of a Dead Reckoning encourages the pilot to consider the safest and most economical flightpath, potential threats and eventual consequences of navigational errors. 2. It is an acceptable and approved mean of navigation. Dead Reckoning can be used to navigate under Visual Flight Rules without having to rely on a radio or other navigational aids. 3. If you are only 20 NM along track, every one degree of drift angle relates to one third of a NM
learning.explanation: The aircraft flying with a GS of 140 kt, experiences a left off-track deviation of 4 NM after: Distance = GS x Time = 140 kt x 12/60 hr = 28 NM. If you are only 20 NM along track, every one degree of drift angle relates to one third of a NM. If so, 2 NM off-track must equate to a 6° drift angle and 3 NM off-track must equate to a 9° drift angle. Applying the 1:60 rule, an aircraft which is off-track 4 NM after 60 NM, will have a drift angle of 4°. Thus, after 28 NM, the aircraft will have a drift angle of: 4 NM x 60 / 28 NM = 8° (rounded).

content.question:
The Earth's spin axis is inclined to the plane of the ecliptic. What effect does that have on the duration of daylight at Cambridge (52°N, 000°E) compared with that at La Palma in the Canary islands (29°N, 018°W) on the same day?
Cambridge will have (1) __ hours of daylight on the 1st July and (2) __ hours of daylight on the 1st January.

key_points: The ecliptic is the name given to the apparent path of the Sun on the celestial sphere
It also refers to the plane of this path and the orbit of the Earth around the Sun and the apparent orbit of the Sun around the Earth
The axis of rotation of the Earth is inclined to this orbital path at an angle of about 66
learning.explanation: The ecliptic is the name given to the apparent path of the Sun on the celestial sphere. It also refers to the plane of this path and the orbit of the Earth around the Sun and the apparent orbit of the Sun around the Earth. The axis of rotation of the Earth is inclined to this orbital path at an angle of about 66.5o, which means that the angle between the plane of ecliptic and the Earth’s equator is 23.5o. When we are at the Equator, the daylight does not vary significantly over the year, whereas if we are near the poles, the difference between summer and winter is very dramatic. When looking at total sunlight received, the poles generally have lower sunlight, because even in their summer, there is much lower land area relative to the equator. The tilt of the Earth of the Earth’s axis also means that in extreme northern and southern latitudes, there will be times of the year in winter when the Sun does not rise and times in summer when it does not set. The time of sunrise and sunset changes very little day by day except at high latitudes. The time of sunrise and sunset varies with latitude and time of year higher latitudes experience longer days in the summer and shorter days in the winter. The reason for the variation of the duration of daylight throughout the year is the inclination of the Earth’s axis of rotation to the ecliptic. Therefore, Cambridge, which has a relatively high latitude (52oN) will have more hours of daylight on the 1st July and fewer hours of daylight on the 1st January.

key_points: The heights on the glideslope can be calculted using the formula: Height difference (ft) = Glidepath Angle(o) x Distance to go (ft) / 60
So, solving for Distance to go, we get: Distance to go (ft) = (Height difference (ft) x 60) / Glidepath angle (o)

learning.explanation: The heights on the glideslope can be calculted using the formula: Height difference (ft) = Glidepath Angle(o) x Distance to go (ft) / 60. So, solving for Distance to go, we get: Distance to go (ft) = (Height difference (ft) x 60) / Glidepath angle (o). The aircraft descends from cruise altitude 4500ft to the traffic pattern altitude 1500 ft, thus the height difference is 3000 ft. Therefore, the horizontal distance covered during the descent is: Distance to go (ft) = (3000 ft x 60) / 3o = 60,000 ft or 60,000ft / 6,080 = 9.86 NM, rounded 10 NM. The aircraft's average Rate of Descent is 850 ft/min, which means that it loses 850 ft in 1 min. Therefore, the aircraft loses 3000 ft in: 3000ft / 850 ft/min = 3.5 minutes or 3 minutes 30 seconds. Finally, the aircraft to reach downwind from cruise altitude 4500 ft to the traffic pattern altitude 1500ft following a 3° glidepath angle, the descent must be initiated at 10 NM prior to downwind, and with a Rate of Descent of 850 ft/min, it will last for 3 minutes 30 seconds.

The drift is the angle difference from the Heading to the Track, so a 7º left drift means that the Track should have a direction 7º less than the Heading. This only applies if they are using the same datum, so both Magnetic, both True, etc. As the variation and deviation are unknown, but definitely NOT zero, Headings and Tracks using different datums cannot be compared (Magnetic Heading and True Track, for instance). Let's consider each option "TH = 186º; MT = 179º" The Heading is True and the Track is Magnetic, these are not comparable, so incorrect. "MH = 179º; MT = 186º" The Track is 7º greater than the Heading, so incorrect. "CH = 179º; MT = 186º" Not comparable, and the Track is 7º greater than the Heading again. Incorrect. "TH = 186º; TT = 179º" Same datum and Track is 7º less than Heading, correct.

key_points: No calculations are required for this question, because it asks for TAS and Mach speed “at some point during climb” and not at a specific altitude during your climb
A usefool tool in determining the changing relationship between EAS, CAS, TAS and Mach in climbs and descents below the tropopause, is the ECTM graphs
CAS can be considered to be identical to IAS
learning.explanation: No calculations are required for this question, because it asks for TAS and Mach speed “at some point during climb” and not at a specific altitude during your climb. A usefool tool in determining the changing relationship between EAS, CAS, TAS and Mach in climbs and descents below the tropopause, is the ECTM graphs. CAS can be considered to be identical to IAS. The ECTM graphs are used to determine what happens to the other three speeds when climbing or descending, whilst holding one speed constant, by drawing initially the parameter that is to be held constant as a vertical line and drawing, later, connecting lines to the remaining letters. The lines are always in the sequence "ECTM", in the standard atmosphere and the speed held constant is drawn vertically. During climb with a constant CAS, both TAS and Mach speed increase. Thus, since at the beginning of the climb the instruments' cross-check shows TAS at 336 kt and Mach speed 0.55, at FL280 both TAS and Mach speeds are expected to be higher. Therefore, the only option that gives both TAS and Mach speed higher than 336 kt and 0.55 correspondingly, is TAS 357 kt and Mach 0.59.

content.question: A pilot plans to fly from an accurate fix at 22:00z with a heading of 175°. The track is planned to fly directly overhead an aerodrome after 37 NM, then continue in the same direction for another 50 NM after that. At 22:14 the aircraft actually passes 5 NM to the right of the aerodrome. What should the pilot make the new heading to reach the next turning point 50 NM away, and what is their new ETA at that turning point?

key_points: The aircraft covers the distance of 37 NM, from the fixpoint to an aerodrome, between 22:00 and 22:14, i
e
in 14 minutes
learning.explanation: The aircraft covers the distance of 37 NM, from the fixpoint to an aerodrome, between 22:00 and 22:14, i.e. in 14 minutes. So its actual Groundspeed is: GS = Distance / Time = 37 NM / (14/60) = 158 kt. Thus, it covers the distance of 50 NM from the aerodrome to the turning point in: Time = Distance / GS = 50 NM / 158 = 0.31 hr or 19 min. Therefore, the aircraft's Estimated Time of Arrival at the turning point will be: 22:14 + 19 min = 22:33. But the aircraft is not above overhead the aerodrome as planned, but 5 NM right off it, because the wind is not as forecast. Using your Navigation/Flight computer follow the steps below: Firstly, find the Track Error Angle, which is also the degrees to parallel: Place the distance off track 5 NM (50) over the distance gone 37 NM and read over the 60 marker the degrees to parallel 8.1o (81) on the outer scale. Secondly, find the degrees to intercept at the next turning point: Place the distance off track 5 NM (50) over the distance to go 50 NM and read over the 60 marker the degrees to get back to track at the turning point 6o (60) on the outer scale. Thus, the total correction to the heading must be: 8.1o + 6o = 14.1o. And since the aircraft is off track to the right, the total correction to the heading must be to the left. Therefore, the heading to intercept the turning point must be: 175o - 14.1o = 160.9o, which is close to 161o.

content.question: A flight leg of 90 NM is planned from A to B via an intermediate point C overhead a railway intersection. The planned heading is 037⁰T and the planned GS is 135 kt. After 12 minutes the pilot notices that he/she is 3 NM ahead and 3NM left of the railway intersection, instead of 1 NM right, as expected. Find the required heading to reach at B.

key_points: The planned GS is 135 kt and after 12 min from A the pilot expected to be overhead the railway intersection, point C
Thus, the distance from A to C is: Planned GS / Planned A - C = (135 kt x 12 min) / 60 = 27 NM
But, the aircraft is 3 NM ahead of point C, thus: 27 NM + 3 NM = 30 NM from A
learning.explanation: The planned GS is 135 kt and after 12 min from A the pilot expected to be overhead the railway intersection, point C. Thus, the distance from A to C is: Planned GS / Planned A - C = (135 kt x 12 min) / 60 = 27 NM. But, the aircraft is 3 NM ahead of point C, thus: 27 NM + 3 NM = 30 NM from A. Thus, the remaining distance after C is: 90 NM - 30 NM = 60 NM. The off - course deviation after 30 NM with reference to point C is: 3 NM left + 1 NM right = 4 NM left. Using your Flight/Nav computer, the corrections that must be made to the heading are: Degrees to parallel: Align distance off, 4 NM (40) outer scale, with distance travelled, 30 NM inner scale. Above the black arrow (60), read the degrees to parallel: 8° (80 ) on the outer scale. Degrees to intercept position B: Align distance off, 4 NM (40) outer scale, with distance to go, 60 NM inner scale. Above the black arrow (60), read the degrees to intercept: 4° (40) on outer scale. Thus, the total heading correction to proceed directly to position B is: 8° + 4° = 12°. And since the deviation is to the left, the heading correction must be to the right. Therefore, the required heading to reach at B is: 037⁰T + 12° = 049⁰T.

content.question: What scenario will give the greatest difference between nautical air miles and ground miles?

key_points: Nautical Air Miles (NAM) is the air distance flown at a given True Airspeed (TAS) and is given by the formula: NAM = TAS x TIME
Nautical Ground Miles (NGM) is the ground distance covered over the Earth's surface at a given Groundspeed (GS) and is given by the formula: NGM = GS x TIME
The air distance (NAM) is equal to the ground distance (NGM) in nil wind conditions
learning.explanation: Nautical Air Miles (NAM) is the air distance flown at a given True Airspeed (TAS) and is given by the formula: NAM = TAS x TIME. Nautical Ground Miles (NGM) is the ground distance covered over the Earth's surface at a given Groundspeed (GS) and is given by the formula: NGM = GS x TIME. The air distance (NAM) is equal to the ground distance (NGM) in nil wind conditions. It is important to note that, as altitude increases, the air distance increases and so does the difference between the air distance and the ground distance - this is due to the curvature of the Earth. The headwind or tailwind component, when applied to the TAS, will give the GS: GS = TAS +/- Tailwind/Headwind. NAM - NGM is greatest when there is a headwind.

learning.explanation: Wind directions True or Magnetic? Any written meteorological information written (TAF, METAR, SIGMET, etc) will be given in true direction. Any information (ATIS, ATC) given to help pilot to line up the aircraft with runway for take-off or landing is magnetic, because runways directions are always magnetic. The wind velocity is made of two components, one acting along the runway called the headwind component, and the other acting across the runway called the crosswind component. It is possible to calculate the crosswind component taking the sine and the cosine of the relative bearing between the runway and the wind direction. key_points: To determine the True Bearing from the aircraft to the Locator PY at 1003 UTC, we can utilize the following equation: True Bearing from the aircraft to the Locator PY (at 1003 UTC) = Relative Bearing of the Locator (at 1003 UTC) + True Heading Given: Relative Bearing of the Locator PY (at 1 003 UTC) = 266º

To calculate the True Heading, both the Track and the Wind Direction must be referenced to the same North (either True or Magnetic)
learning.explanation: To determine the True Bearing from the aircraft to the Locator PY at 1003 UTC, we can utilize the following equation: True Bearing from the aircraft to the Locator PY (at 1003 UTC) = Relative Bearing of the Locator (at 1003 UTC) + True Heading Given: Relative Bearing of the Locator PY (at 1 003 UTC) = 266º. Therefore, we need to calculate the True Heading. To calculate the True Heading, both the Track and the Wind Direction must be referenced to the same North (either True or Magnetic). We will be converting the Track from Magnetic to True. By considering the provided magnetic variation: Variation = 5º W ⇒ Variation West, Magnetic Best ⇒ True Track = Magnetic Track - 005º = 007º - 005º = 002º. Given that True Track = 002º, TAS = 445 kt, and W/V: 050º/40 kt, we can use a flight computer to determine the true heading: Rotate the window disc until the True Wind Direction (050º) aligns below the TRUE HEADING index on the fixed scale. Shift the slide until the center dot aligns with the arc corresponding to the True Airspeed (445 kt). Wind correction angle reads between centre line and Wind speed Mark => 4°R. 4ºR WCA means that the aircraft is experiencing a 4ºL drift. Therefore, Heading = Track + drift = 002°+ 004°= 006° Finally, applying the relationship above, we obtain: True Bearing from the aircraft to the Locator PY (at 1 003 UTC) = 266º + 006º = 272º.

content.question: An aircraft departs point A (26°06'N,004°11'E) and flies directly south for 500 NM to point B. From point B, the aircraft flies directly east for 500 NM to point C. The coordinates of point C are…

key_points: The aircraft initially flies south, so it flies along the meridian 004°11'E
Along a meridian "1 minute of latitude equals to 1 NM"
Thus, a distance of 500 NM along a meridian corresponds to 500' change of latitude or 8° 20'
learning.explanation: The aircraft initially flies south, so it flies along the meridian 004°11'E. Along a meridian "1 minute of latitude equals to 1 NM". Thus, a distance of 500 NM along a meridian corresponds to 500' change of latitude or 8° 20'. Therefore, as it flies south on the northern hemisphere, its latitude will decrease, provided that it does not cross the Equator. Its new latitude at B point, after 500 NM south off A point, will be: 26°06'N - 8° 20' = 17°46'N. After B point, the aircraft continues eastwards (i.e. along the same parallel of latitude) for 500 NM along the 17°46'N parallel of latitude. The distance along a parallel of latitude is called "Departure" and is given by the formula: Departure(NM) = Change of Longitude(min) x cos Lat. Solving for Change of Longitude we get: Change of Longitude(min) = Departure(NM) / cos Lat = 500 NM / cos 17°46' = 525 or 8° 45'. Therefore, its new longitude, after 500 NM east off B point, will be: 004°11' + 8° 45' = 012°56' E. Finally, C position's coordinates will be: 17°46'N 012°56' E.

key_points: Mathematicians and scientists call a quantity which depends on direction a vector quantity
A quantity which does not depend on direction is called a scalar quantity
A vector quantity has two characteristics, a magnitude and a direction
learning.explanation: Mathematicians and scientists call a quantity which depends on direction a vector quantity. A quantity which does not depend on direction is called a scalar quantity. A vector quantity has two characteristics, a magnitude and a direction. When comparing two vector quantities of the same type, you have to compare both the magnitude and the direction,Vectors are usually denoted on figures by an arrow. The length of the arrow indicates the magnitude and the tip of the arrow indicates the direction. content.question: The inclination of the Earth's spin axis in relation to the plane of rotation around the Sun is the cause of the variable amount of (1) _____ and the changing duration of (2) _____ throughout the year at mid and high latitudes.

key_points: Insolation is a measure of solar radiation energy received on a given surface area in a given time
Solar energy is created at the core of the Sun and hits the Earth with an intensity depending on its angle of arrival

The angle of arrival at any point, as a result of the Earth's axis inclination in relation to the plane of rotation, is dependent on its latitude, the season, as the Earth axis tilts in relation to the Sun and the time of day
learning.explanation: Insolation is a measure of solar radiation energy received on a given surface area in a given time. Solar energy is created at the core of the Sun and hits the Earth with an intensity depending on its angle of arrival. The angle of arrival at any point, as a result of the Earth's axis inclination in relation to the plane of rotation, is dependent on its latitude, the season, as the Earth axis tilts in relation to the Sun and the time of day. Also, the Earth's axis inclination in relation to the plane of rotation around the Sun, is responsible for the changing duration of the daylight throughout the year at mid and high latitudes. When the northern hemisphere is tilted most towards the Sun, it experiences northern hemisphere summer, when it tilts most away, it experiences northern hemisphere winter, but southern hemisphere summer. The tilt of the Earth’s axis also accounts for longer nights in winter and longer days in summer.

content.question: An aircraft is flying at a pressure altitude of 10 000 feet in conditions where the temperature is -15°C (ISA). If the recorded ground speed is 485 knots and there is a headwind component of 25 knots, what is the True Airspeed (TAS) of the aircraft?

key_points: Learning Objectives 061
learning.explanation: Learning Objectives 061.01.05.04.02: Apply HWC and TWC to determine GS from TAS and vice versa. The question provides a lot of data, but to find the True Airspeed (TAS), we only need the Ground Speed (GS) and the wind component. With a headwind, the TAS is higher than the GS because the wind is slowing you down. Therefore, you add the headwind component to the GS. With a tailwind, the TAS is lower than the GS because the wind is pushing you faster. Therefore, you subtract the tailwind component from the GS. Here's the formula to calculate TAS: TAS = GS ± Headwind/Tailwind Component - Use the plus sign if it’s a headwind (wind blowing against the direction of travel). - Use the minus sign if it’s a tailwind (wind blowing in the same direction as travel). Given: Ground Speed (GS) = 485 knots Headwind Component = 25 knots Since it's a headwind, you add the headwind component to the ground speed to find the TAS. TAS = GS + Headwind Component TAS = 485 kt + 25 kt TAS = 510 kt

Thus, its Change of Longitude in minutes is 360o or 360o x 60' = 21600'
The distance along a parallel of latitude is given by the formula: Departure (NM) = Change of Longitude (min) x Cos of Latitude = 21600' x Cos 88o = 753
learning.explanation: "An aircraft circles the earth" means that the aircraft flies for 360o Change of Longitude, so the departure and destination point is the same. Based in the calculation of the position of airplane based in the direction and the ground distance traveled from a determined point
With the introduction of modern navigational techniques such as GPS and conventional radio navigational aids, this may seem outdated technique
learning.explanation: Navigation by Dead Reckoning is part of the basic training for pilots. Based in the calculation of the position of airplane based in the direction and the ground distance traveled from a determined point. With the introduction of modern navigational techniques such as GPS and conventional radio navigational aids, this may seem outdated technique. Reasons for why we continue to teach Dead Reckoning: 1. Creation of a Dead Reckoning encourages the pilot to consider the safest and most economical flightpath, potential threats and eventual consequences of navigational errors. 2. It is an acceptable and approved mean of navigation. Dead Reckoning can be used to navigate under Visual Flight Rules without having to rely on a radio or other navigational aids. 3. It is fail-safe mean of navigation. DR does not rely on any navigational aid, it is therefore a valuable contingency navigation method, even if the the plan is to fly with. Reference to a GPS or other navigation aid.

content.question: An aircraft's compass reads 002°. The deviation card shows 1°W on northerly headings and the variation is 5°W. What is the aircraft's true heading?

key_points: True Direction, the North Pole is taken as a geographic reference and is assigned an angular value of 000º T or 360º T
In most light aircraft True directions aren’t the most precise because the airplanes aren’t equipped with instruments that will align itself with the True North Pole
The primary source for directions inside a cockpit is the magnetic compass and he will align itself with the Magnetic North Pole and not with the True North Pole, those are not co-located
learning.explanation: True Direction, the North Pole is taken as a geographic reference and is assigned an angular value of 000º T or 360º T. In most light aircraft True directions aren’t the most precise because the airplanes aren’t equipped with instruments that will align itself with the True North Pole. The primary source for directions inside a cockpit is the magnetic compass and he will align itself with the Magnetic North Pole and not with the True North Pole, those are not co-located. Magnetic Direction, have as reference the Magnetic North Pole and is assigned an angular value of 000º M or 360º M. Variation is the angle between the True and Magnetic North and is assigned in degrees East or West of the True North. If the Magnetic North is west of the True North, westerly variation, the magnetic direction will have a higher angular value than the true direction. If the Magnetic North is east of the True North, easterly variation, the magnetic direction will have a lower angular value than the true direction. Variation (-) West – Magnetic Best Variation (+) East – Magnetic Least The utility of a magnetic compass on the aircraft will depend on the accuracy of its response to the magnetic field of the earth. The metallic structure of the airplane, its engine and equipment can affect the accuracy of the compass, an effect called the compass deviation. Compass deviation is defined by the number of degrees by which unwanted magnetic fields deflect the compass from magnetic north indication (desired indication). Deviation (-) West – Compass Best Deviation (+) East – Compass Least The relationship between the different directions can be expressed by the following table: True Heading (T) Variation (V) Magnetic Heading (M) Deviation (D) Compass Heading (C) 356º 5ºW 001º 1ºW 002º Note: The TVMDC table can be used to relate both Heading directions or track directions.

content.question: Which combination represents the greatest difference between the air distance and the ground distance for two points?

learning.explanation: In still air conditions and at Sea Level, the air distance between two points is equal to their ground distance. content.question: An aircraft commences to descent from a Top of Descent at 35 000 ft and 75 NM from the Initial Approach Fix, at which it has to level-off at 7500 feet altitude. What descent gradient is required to achieved the forementioned requirements?

key_points: A gradient can be expressed in a number of ways
The simplest is to describe how many units of horizontal distance are required for every unit of height gained or lost
This can also be expressed as a ratio, a fraction or a decimal (1 in 10, 1:10, 1/10 or 0
learning.explanation: A gradient can be expressed in a number of ways. The simplest is to describe how many units of horizontal distance are required for every unit of height gained or lost. This can also be expressed as a ratio, a fraction or a decimal (1 in 10, 1:10, 1/10 or 0.10), but the most common is in percentage and is given by the formula: % Gradient = Change of height x 100 / Horizontal distance. For this question, the Change of height is: 35 000 ft - 7 500 ft = 27 500 ft. Thus, the required Descent Gradient is: % Gradient = 27 500 ft x 100 / (75 NM x 6080 ft) = 6.03 %, which is very close to 6.1 %.

content.question: The pilot of an aircraft during descent with constant CAS of 120 kt, observes a TAS of 135 kt at FL080. What will be the TAS, if he/she checks again the instruments minutes later?

key_points: The dynamic pressure is the basic measure of airspeed in the aircraft
The Airspeed Indicators are calibrated to read corrrectly at Sea Level ISA conditions
At a height the air density reduces and therefore the same dynamic pressure reflects a higher TAS
learning.explanation: The dynamic pressure is the basic measure of airspeed in the aircraft. The Airspeed Indicators are calibrated to read corrrectly at Sea Level ISA conditions. At a height the air density reduces and therefore the same dynamic pressure reflects a higher TAS. The same thing would happen, if the air was warmer than standard. Conversely, at a lower height or in colder air than standard, the same dynamic presssure reflects a lower TAS. This means that at height we have two airspeeds, the CAS based on dynamic pressure and the higher TAS than CAS through the air. As an aircraft descends from one altitude to one other lower with constant CAS, but higher to Sea Level, the TAS will be in both cases higher than the CAS, but the difference between them increases as altitude increases and decreases as altitude decreases, until they become equal at Sea Level in ISA conditions. For this question, the TAS will be always higher than CAS during the descent (thus, 119 kt is excluded), but a few minutes later, after FL080, the TAS will be lower than 135 kt, 131 kt.

content.question: You depart point A at 12:15 and begin a planned route of 80 NM. Your initial heading is 235º. At 12:27 you pass a rail track crossing your path at 90º after travelling 40 NM. At 12:33 the pilot realizes he/she is 4 NM to the left of the intended track. What heading should you fly to reach your intended destination and what will be your ETA?

key_points: With the information provided by the question text, we can calculate the aircraft’s ground speed
The aircraft departs at 12:15 and we know that at 12:27 (after 12 minutes), the aircraft has covered 40 NM

Ground speed = (40 ÷ 12) x 60 = 200 kt At 12:33, the aircraft would have covered a further 20 NM: 12:33 – 12:27 = 6 min (200 kt x 6 min) / 60 = 20 NM At 40 NM + 20 NM = 60 NM along the route (12:33), the aircraft is 4 NM to the left of the intended track
learning.explanation: With the information provided by the question text, we can calculate the aircraft’s ground speed. The aircraft departs at 12:15 and we know that at 12:27 (after 12 minutes), the aircraft has covered 40 NM. Ground speed = (40 ÷ 12) x 60 = 200 kt At 12:33, the aircraft would have covered a further 20 NM: 12:33 – 12:27 = 6 min (200 kt x 6 min) / 60 = 20 NM At 40 NM + 20 NM = 60 NM along the route (12:33), the aircraft is 4 NM to the left of the intended track. Calculate the TKE (Track Angle Error) to give us the heading correction in order to parallel our intended track: TKE = (distance off track × 60) ÷ distance along track TKE = (4 × 60) ÷ 60 TKE = 4° If we alter our heading by 4° (towards the original track) we will parallel our original track. In order to re-join the original track, we must calculate the track correction for the distance to go: TKE = (distance off track × 60) ÷ distance to go TKE = (4 × 60) ÷ 20 TKE = 12º So turning 4° will parallel our track, and turning an extra 12° on top of that will direct us to the final destination. Therefore, 4° + 12° = 16º would be the total alteration required (to re-join the original track). The deviation was to the left, therefore we must fly 16º to the right. Track = 235º + 16º = 251º The aircraft 80 NM – 60 NM = 20 NM away from the destination. At 200 kt, it will cover 20 NM in 6 minutes. The destination will be reached at 12:33 + 6 min = 12:39

content.question: Plotting positions in charts by Dead Reckoning (DR) may be required..

options.A: in areas with high densities of airways and navigation aids.
options.B: during a flight over sea using INS/IRS and GPS navigation.
options.C: during a flight with limited equipment and few navigational aids.

key_points: Navigation by Dead Reckoning is part of the basic training for pilots
Based in the calculation of the position of airplane based in the direction and the ground distance traveled from a determined point
With the introduction of modern navigational techniques such as GPS and conventional radio navigational aids, this may seem outdated technique
learning.explanation: Navigation by Dead Reckoning is part of the basic training for pilots. Based in the calculation of the position of airplane based in the direction and the ground distance traveled from a determined point. With the introduction of modern navigational techniques such as GPS and conventional radio navigational aids, this may seem outdated technique. Reasons for why we continue to teach Dead Reckoning: 1. Creation of a Dead Reckoning encourages the pilot to consider the safest and most economical flightpath, potential threats and eventual consequences of navigational errors. 2. It is an acceptable and approved mean of navigation. Dead Reckoning can be used to navigate under Visual Flight Rules without having to rely on a radio or other navigational aids. 3. It is fail-safe mean of navigation. DR does not rely on any navigational aid, it is therefore a valuable contingency navigation method, even if the the plan is to fly with. Reference to a GPS or other navigation aid.

In most light aircraft True directions aren’t the most precise because the airplanes aren’t equipped with instruments that will align itself with the True North Pole. The primary source for directions inside a cockpit is the magnetic compass and he will align itself with the Magnetic North Pole and not with the True North Pole, those are not co-located. Magnetic Direction, have as reference the Magnetic North Pole and is assigned an angular value of 000º M or 360º M. Variation is the angle between the True and Magnetic North and is assigned in degrees East or West of the True North. If the Magnetic North is west of the True North, westerly variation, the magnetic direction will have a higher angular value than the true direction. If the Magnetic North is east of the True North, easterly variation, the magnetic direction will have a lower angular value than the true direction. Variation (-) West – Magnetic Best Variation (+) East – Magnetic Least The utility of a magnetic compass on the aircraft will depend on the accuracy of its response to the magnetic field of the earth. The metallic structure of the airplane, its engine and equipment can affect the accuracy of the compass, an effect called the compass deviation. Compass deviation is defined by the number of degrees by which unwanted magnetic fields deflect the compass from magnetic north indication (desired indication). Deviation (-) West – Compass Best Deviation (+) East – Compass Least Drift or drift angle, is the angular difference between the track of the aircraft across and it's heading. Always remember that the drift angle is always measured with reference to the heading. The heading is the direction in witch the the aircraft’s nose is pointing for. learning.explanation: Magnetic variation is the angle between the true meridian and the magnetic meridian. It varies across the Earth between 180º, on a line joining the true and magnetic poles (the magnetic compass is pointing at the Magnetic North Pole, whilst the tail of the needle is pointing at the Geographic North Pole) and 0º, where this line is extended beyond the poles. Lines joining points of equal variation on the Earth's surface are called "isogonals" and the line along which variation is zero is called "agonic line". content.question:
Given:
Distance A to B = 150 NM.After 30 NM aircraft is 4 NM to the right of course.What heading alteration should be made in order to arrive at point "B"?

key_points: It is normal during flight that the track over the ground is different from the desired trajectory defined during planning

learning.explanation: It is normal during flight that the track over the ground is different from the desired trajectory defined during planning. If this is the case, some heading corrections should be made so that we can return to the track. The track you want to fly is the planned track, and the track you actually make over the ground is the track made good. The difference between them is called track error (TE). The angle at which we want to close to come back to the planned track is the closing angle (CA). The CA will depend how much further we want to rejoin the planned track. The 1 in 60 rule can be used to calculate the TE and the CA. TE = (distance off-track/planned track distance flown) x 60 TE = (4/30) x 60 = 8º The same 1 in 60 rule can be applied to calculate the CA. CA = (distance off-track/distance at which we want to rejoin track) x 60 CA = (4 / (150 - 30)) x 60 = 2º With both TE and CA, we can determine by how much heading change we should apply to regain track: Heading change = TE + CA = 8º + 2º = 10º L The aircraft is right off-track, the aircraft must fly left to regain track.

learning.explanation: True Direction, the North Pole is taken as a geographic reference and is assigned an angular value of 000º T or 360º T. In most light aircraft True directions aren’t the most precise because the airplanes aren’t equipped with instruments that will align itself with the True North Pole. The primary source for directions inside a cockpit is the magnetic compass and he will align itself with the Magnetic North Pole and not with the True North Pole, those are not co-located. Magnetic Direction, have as reference the Magnetic North Pole and is assigned an angular value of 000º M or 360º M. Variation is the angle between the True and Magnetic North and is assigned in degrees East or West of the True North. If the Magnetic North is west of the True North, westerly variation, the magnetic direction will have a higher angular value than the true direction. If the Magnetic North is east of the True North, easterly variation, the magnetic direction will have a lower angular value than the true direction. The metallic structure of the airplane, its engine and equipment can affect the accuracy of the compass, an effect called the compass deviation. Compass deviation is defined by the number of degrees by which unwanted magnetic fields deflect the compass from magnetic north indication (desired indication). content.question: The charted values of magnetic variation on Earth normally change annually due to...

options.A: an increasing field strength causing numerical values at all locations to increase.
options.B: magnetic pole movement causing numerical values at all locations to increase or decrease.
options.C: a reducing field strength causing numerical values at all locations to decrease.
options.D: magnetic pole movement causing numerical values at all locations to increase.

key_points: The magnetic variation is caused by the different locations of the geographic (true) North Pole and the magnetic North Pole
The horizontal component of the Earth’s magnetic field is the part that is detected by the compass needle in order to determine Magnetic North
Therefore, it is accurate enough to say that variation is the angle between the horizontal component of the magnetic field and the true north direction
learning.explanation: The magnetic variation is caused by the different locations of the geographic (true) North Pole and the magnetic North Pole. The horizontal component of the Earth’s magnetic field is the part that is detected by the compass needle in order to determine Magnetic North. Therefore, it is accurate enough to say that variation is the angle between the horizontal component of the magnetic field and the true north direction. At a specific location, the value of magnetic variation varies slowly over time. In fact, the magnetic pole is constantly moving, causing the values at all locations to increase or decrease. This periodic change is also reflected in the slow movement of the magnetic poles monitored through the various ground and satellite-based stations/instruments. The IRS of the aircraft also contains a variation program. It is supplied to the IRS true North to obtain a magnetic heading, which is ultimately fed to the FMS. The IRS is also normally recalibrated from time to time so that it can maintain the variation accurately enough. Lately, the magnetic pole location is changing more rapidly, approximately at a rate of 30 to 40 miles per year, moving towards Siberia. The need to continuously monitor and update the magnetic variation charts is, therefore, more crucial than ever. LO 061.01.03.01.05: Explain changes of variation with time and position.

An aircraft is following the flight log, and during the flight the wind has been as forecast. Between the M20 junction and the DET VOR, the pilot diverts from the route to avoid low clouds. By the 1:60 rule, the magnetic heading to fly to arrive at the DET VOR is...

key_points: The 1:60 rule states that: "For each degree of track error you will be one NM off-track having travelled 60 NM along track"
So, if you have travelled for 30 NM the error will be half NM per degree of track error or, if you have travelled for 20 NM, one third NM per degree of track error
If the track error is larger, the error will be proportionally larger, so 60 NM along track a 2o track error will place you 2 NM off track, or 1 NM off track after 30 NM
learning.explanation: The 1:60 rule states that: "For each degree of track error you will be one NM off-track having travelled 60 NM along track". So, if you have travelled for 30 NM the error will be half NM per degree of track error or, if you have travelled for 20 NM, one third NM per degree of track error. If the track error is larger, the error will be proportionally larger, so 60 NM along track a 2o track error will place you 2 NM off track, or 1 NM off track after 30 NM. The rule can be used to determine the track error angle,when the displacement is known, the displacement, when the track is known and correction to intercept, when displacement is known. The correction that must be made to intercept the DET VOR is given by the following formula, which is based on the 1:60 rule: (Distance off track / Miles to go) = (Degrees to intrercept / 60). Solving for Degrees to intercept we get: Degrees to intercept = (Distance off track x 60) / Miles to go = (2.5 NM x 60) / (27 NM - 15 NM) = 12.5o. Thus, since the aircraft is off-track to the left, the correction that must be made to arrive at DET VOR must be to the right, and its magnetic heading must be: Planned Magnetic Heading from M20 junction to DET VOR + Degrees to intercept = 283o (M) + 12.5o = 295.5o, which is very close to 296o.

content.question: What is the only true great circle on the surface of the WGS-84 ellipsoid?

options.A: The great circle that crosses the Equator at 045º (T).
options.B: The track along any meridian from pole to pole.
options.C: The great circle that is coincident with the Equator.

key_points: The planet of the Earth is roughly spherical
Because of its spin, it is slightly fatter at the Equator and slightly flattened at the poles, a shape known as an oblate spheroid or an ellipsoid
On the WGS-84 reference system, the Earth's shape is very close to this kind of ellipsoid
learning.explanation: The planet of the Earth is roughly spherical. Because of its spin, it is slightly fatter at the Equator and slightly flattened at the poles, a shape known as an oblate spheroid or an ellipsoid. On the WGS-84 reference system, the Earth's shape is very close to this kind of ellipsoid. The Prime Meridian and its anti-meridian form an ellipse which is not a great circle. Thus, the only true great circle on the surface of the WGS-84 ellipsoid is the great circle that is coincident with the Equator.

Given that the ADF is tuned to an NDB, the ADF needle on the RMI works as follows: The Tip of the ADF needle indicates the Compass bearing to the NDB (300°). The Tail of the ADF needle indicates the Compass bearing from the NDB (120°). In this case, we assume that the RMI is subjected to electromagnetic interference and therefore, deviation is applied: -2ºW (westerly deviation) ⇒ Compass North is 2° West of Magnetic North. Let’s start by converting compass heading to magnetic heading: Deviation west, compass best; Deviation east, compass least Magnetic Bearing to the NDB = Compass Bearing to the NDB - 002° = 300° - 002° = 298° Since the question asks for true bearing, we need to correct for magnetic variation: Variation west, magnetic best; Variation east, magnetic least. Remember that for NDB/ADF bearings the bearings are taken at the aircraft, therefore the magnetic variation applicable at the aircraft's position is to be used: Variation at the DR position = 22° West ⇒ Magnetic North is 22° West of True North True Bearing to the NDB = Magnetic Bearing to the NDB - 022° = 298° - 022° = 276°

Any information (ATIS, ATC) given to help pilot to line up the aircraft with runway for take-off or landing is magnetic, because runways directions are always magnetic

Any information (ATIS, ATC) given to help pilot to line up the aircraft with runway for take-off or landing is magnetic, because runways directions are always magnetic. The wind velocity is made of two components, one acting along the runway called the headwind component, and the other acting across the runway called the crosswind component. It is possible to calculate the crosswind component taking the sine and the cosine of the relative bearing between the runway and the wind direction. Head/Tail wind component = Wind Speed x cosine (Relative Bearing) Crosswind component = Wind Speed x sine (Relative Bearing) Both indications are already magnetic, and and the worst scenario of wind speed is considered: Crosswind component = 30 x sine (347 - 50) = 27 kts

content.question: The value for variation changes with…

key_points: The poles of the Earth's magnetic field are close to the geographic poles, which lie on the axis of the Earth's rotation, but not coincident, so that a compass pointing to magnetic north will not point exactly at the geographic north pole
The angle between the true meridian and the magnetic meridian, or the difference between the true north and the magnetic north, is called variation and varies between 180o and zero

Because the Earth's magnetic pole is slowly moving around, the variation changes over time and therefore the date of any map showing variation is important, because if it is an old map, its variations will be incorrect
learning.explanation: The poles of the Earth's magnetic field are close to the geographic poles, which lie on the axis of the Earth's rotation, but not coincident, so that a compass pointing to magnetic north will not point exactly at the geographic north pole. The angle between the true meridian and the magnetic meridian, or the difference between the true north and the magnetic north, is called variation and varies between 180o and zero. Because the Earth's magnetic pole is slowly moving around, the variation changes over time and therefore the date of any map showing variation is important, because if it is an old map, its variations will be incorrect. Thus, the pilots should always fly with the most up-to-date chart for flight safety reasons. If the chart is republished at frequent intervals, the variation should be comparatively recent as well.

learning.explanation: When a magnetic needle is influenced only by the Earth’s magnetic field, it points to magnetic north. content.question: Seasons are due to the…

options.A: Earth’s rotation on its polar axis.
options.B: inclination of the polar axis with the ecliptic plane.
options.C: variable distance between the Earth and the Sun.
options.D: Earth’s elliptical orbit around the Sun.

key_points: All planetary orbits, including the Earth's, are elliptical with the Sun at one focus
The Earth moves slightly closer and further away from the Sun during its yearly orbit
The point where the Sun is furthest from the Earth is Aphelion and where it is closest, Perihelion
learning.explanation: All planetary orbits, including the Earth's, are elliptical with the Sun at one focus. The Earth moves slightly closer and further away from the Sun during its yearly orbit. The point where the Sun is furthest from the Earth is Aphelion and where it is closest, Perihelion. The highest speed of the Earth in its orbit is at perihelion, the lowest at aphelion. Perihelion occurs in early January and Aphelion in early July. These differences in range are not enough to cause the seasons, but these come from the Earth's tilt or, using astronomic terminology, the inclination of the Earth's axis of rotation to the ecliptic (where ecliptic, the name given to the apparent path of the Sun on the celestial sphere). When the northern hemisphre is tilted most towards the Sun, it experiences northern hemisphere summer. When it tilts most away, it is northern hemisphere winter, but southern hemisphere summer.

learning.explanation: A freely suspended magnet will align itself with the Earth's magnetic field. The total field (T) is resolved into a horizontal component (H) and a vertical component (Z). content.question: When is the Earth farthest from the Sun (Aphelion)?

key_points: All planetary orbits, including the Earth's, are elliptical with the Sun at one focus
The Earth moves slightly closer and further away from the Sun during its yearly orbit
The point where the Sun is furthest from the Earth is Aphelion and where it is closest, Perihelion
learning.explanation: All planetary orbits, including the Earth's, are elliptical with the Sun at one focus. The Earth moves slightly closer and further away from the Sun during its yearly orbit. The point where the Sun is furthest from the Earth is Aphelion and where it is closest, Perihelion. The highest speed of the Earth in its orbit is at perihelion, the lowest at aphelion. Perihelion occurs in early January and Aphelion in early July. This must not be mistaken for the cause of the seasons, as actually the Earth is farthest from the Sun in early July, and therefore receives slightly less energy per day, and yet the Northern Hemisphere is in the height of Summer. The seasons are instead set by the inclination (tilt) of the Earth.

content.question:
An aircraft is passing point A at 12:05 with a GS of 140 kt. ETA at point B is 13:20. At 12:35, a deviation of 7 NM left of the intended track is noticed. To fly direct to point B from this point the pilot must change his/her track:
(Note: use 1:60 rule)

key_points: It is normal during flight that the track over the ground is different from the desired trajectory defined during planning
If this is the case, some heading corrections should be made so that we can return to the track
The track you want to fly is the planned track, and the track you actually make over the ground is the track made good
learning.explanation: It is normal during flight that the track over the ground is different from the desired trajectory defined during planning. If this is the case, some heading corrections should be made so that we can return to the track. The track you want to fly is the planned track, and the track you actually make over the ground is the track made good. The difference between them is called track error (TE). The angle at which we want to close to come back to the planned track is the closing angle (CA). The CA will depend how much further we want to rejoin the planned track. The 1 in 60 rule can be used to calculate the TE and the CA. TE = (distance off-track/planned track distance flown) x 60 Planned track distance flown = 140 x 30’ = 70 NM TE = (7/70) x 60 = 6º The same 1 in 60 rule can be applied to calculate the CA. CA = (distance off-track/distance at which we want to rejoin track) x 60 Distance at which we want to rejoin track = 140 x 45’ = 105 NM CA = (7/105) x 60 = 4º With both TE and CA, we can determine by how much heading change we should apply to regain track: Heading change = TE + CA = 6º + 4º = 10º R The aircraft is left off-track, the aircraft must fly right to regain track.

content.question: The diameter of the Earth is approximately...

key_points: The diameter of Earth depends on where you are measuring it from
The Earth is not a perfect sphere, and so it has a different diameter around the equator than it does from pole to pole
We know that at the Equator, 1º Longitude = 1NM
learning.explanation: The diameter of Earth depends on where you are measuring it from. The Earth is not a perfect sphere, and so it has a different diameter around the equator than it does from pole to pole. We know that at the Equator, 1º Longitude = 1NM. Based on that, the circumference of the Earth may be calculated as follows: Earth circumference at the Equator = 360º x 60 NM = 21 600 NM => 21 600 NM x 1.852 = 40 000 km Circumference = π x diameter (π = 3.14) 40 000 km = π x diameter diameter = 40 000 km ÷ π diameter = 12 732 km Alternatively, you can just remember that the Earth's circumference (the distance all the way around the equator) is approximately 40 000 km (21 600 NM) and its diameter (the distance from one side to the other through Earth's center) is roughly 12 700 km.

Refer to figure.
The pilot of a light twin-engined aircraft has filled in the flight log correctly for a charter flight to Nice in France, with the fuel recorded in litres. What is the new estimated remaining fuel at EBROX?

key_points: The aircraft covered the flight leg from SOPET to TORDU in: 06:46 - 06:34 = 12 min
So, its Actual Groundspeed will be: Leg distance / Leg time = (37 NM / 12 min) x 60 = 185 kt
The aircraft from SOPET to TORDU burnt: 415 lt - 385 lt = 30 lt in 12 min
learning.explanation: The aircraft covered the flight leg from SOPET to TORDU in: 06:46 - 06:34 = 12 min. So, its Actual Groundspeed will be: Leg distance / Leg time = (37 NM / 12 min) x 60 = 185 kt. The aircraft from SOPET to TORDU burnt: 415 lt - 385 lt = 30 lt in 12 min. Thus, its Actual Fuel Flow is: 30 lt / 12 min = 2.5 lt/min. The FL, TAS, Track, Heading and Groundspeed remain unchanged from TORDU to EBROX. So, the Flight time from TORDU via LOTOS to EBROX is: Leg distance / Actual GS = (26 NM + 14 NM) / 185 kt = 0.22 hr or 13 min. And, the fuel required from TORDU via LOTOS to EBROX will be: Actual fuel flow x Flight leg time = 2.5 lt/min x 13 min = 32.5 lt. Therefore, the new estimated remaining fuel at EBROX will be: Remaining fuel at TORDU - Fuel required from TORDU to EBROX = 385 lt - 32.5 lt = 352.5 lt, which is very close to 353 lt.

content.question: The BUN VOR/DME is located at 51°07'N,004°50'E where the variation is 0°. An aircraft is flying a true course of 090°, starting at 53°04'N, 003°37'E with the BUN turned on the VOR. When the VOR shows a radial of 360°, what is the range of the aircraft from the BUN?

key_points: Where Variation is 0o, the true meridians coincide with the magnetic ones
Radials are magnetic bearings emanated from VORs, so a 360o radial has a northerly magnetic direction
090° true course means that the aircraft flies eastwards and almost along the same parallel of latitude
learning.explanation: Where Variation is 0o, the true meridians coincide with the magnetic ones. Radials are magnetic bearings emanated from VORs, so a 360o radial has a northerly magnetic direction. 090° true course means that the aircraft flies eastwards and almost along the same parallel of latitude. Thus, its latitude (53°04'N) remains constant, when it crosses the R360 BUN. Variation is 0o, so R360 coincides with the true meridian 004°50'E, which passes through the BUN VOR. The range between the aircraft crossing R360 BUN and BUN VOR is equal to their the Change of Latitude. So, applying the rule "Same hemispheres, Subtract", the Change of Latitude along the true meridian or R360 is: 53o04’N - 51o07’N = 1o 57’ or 117’. We know, also, that "Along a meridian, 1’ corresponds to 1NM". Therefore, the range of the aircraft from the BUN VOR when crossing R360 is 117NM.

content.question: What is the definition of the Geodetic Longitude?

options.A: The angle in the equatorial plane between the line a that connects the Earth's centre with the prime meridian and the line b that connects the centre with the meridian on which the point lies.
options.B: The distance in the equatorial plane between the line a that connects the Earth's centre with the prime meridian and the line b that connects the centre with the meridian on which the point lies.
options.C: The angle in the equatorial plane between the line a that connects the Earth's centre with the prime meridian and the line b that connects the centre with the anti-meridian of the point.
options.D: The distance in the equatorial plane between the line a that connects the Earth's centre with the prime meridian and the line b that connects the centre with the anti-meridian of the point.

key_points: Latitude and longitude are the grid lines you see on globes
Longitude is the angle in the equatorial plane
There is no natural reference for longitude, but the zero line, called the "prime meridian", is taken, by convention, as the line through Greenwich England
learning.explanation: Latitude and longitude are the grid lines you see on globes. Longitude is the angle in the equatorial plane. There is no natural reference for longitude, but the zero line, called the "prime meridian", is taken, by convention, as the line through Greenwich England. For a spherical Earth, latitude and longitude are angles seen from the center of the Earth and only for the longitude is the exactly the same as for an ellipsoid Earth. Geodetic latitude and longitude is used to define a position on the WGS 84 ellipsoid for aviation charts. Geodetic longitude is defined as "The angular distance between the prime meridian and another meridian passing through a point on the Earth's surface" or "The angle in the equatorial plane between the line a that connects the Earth's centre with the prime meridian and the line b that connects the centre with the meridian on which the point lies". Because the vertex of the angle is the centre of the Earth, the same as for geocentric longitude, the value is the same for both types of longitude.

learning.explanation: There are two possible answers for this question. However, the option "By selecting a suitable echo from the display, obtaining the relative bearing and distance, and converting it into a true bearing to plot on the chart." has been confirmed by feedback to be correct in official exams. The pilot may take a relative bearing from an AWR display and would then use the aircraft heading to turn the relative heading into a magnetic or true bearing to. Thereafter, the reciprocal from the ground feature can be back-plotted as true or magnetic. On the other hand, putting the AWR into "mapping" mode allows the radar to reflect off surface features, which can give quite a good indication of the ground profile nearby. For instance, ground mapping radar can allow pilots to distinguish coastlines quite easily, as well as mountain ranges and sometimes even cities. To establish a fix, the pilots would place the AWR in mapping mode and/or tilt the radar down a lot, then look for echoes on the display that show these features, comparing that with a chart to get an idea of their position. It is certainly a skill, and not one that will be passed through the generations of pilots very well in the modern era, as it is almost useless these days. content.question: A pilot during the pre-flight planning procedure uses an aeronautical chart to find the magnetic variation. Which statement is correct regarding the magnetic variation at a specific position?

options.A: Magnetic variation decreases with time due to the half-value time of magnetic material in the earth.
options.B: Magnetic variation changes due to the changing position of the magnetic material in the Earth.
options.C: Magnetic variation always increases by approximately 1° every 5 years.
options.D: Magnetic variation changes occur mainly due to the intense solar storms.

key_points: The poles of the Earth's magnetic field are close to the geographic poles, which lie on the axis of the Earth's rotation, but not coincident, so that a compass pointing to magnetic north will not point exactly at the geographic north pole
The angle between the true meridian and the magnetic meridian, or the difference between the true north and the magnetic north, is called variation and varies between 180o and zero
Due to the dynamic nature of the earth’s interior, due to the changing position of the magnetic material in the Earth, the magnetic field is constantly changing
learning.explanation: The poles of the Earth's magnetic field are close to the geographic poles, which lie on the axis of the Earth's rotation, but not coincident, so that a compass pointing to magnetic north will not point exactly at the geographic north pole. The angle between the true meridian and the magnetic meridian, or the difference between the true north and the magnetic north, is called variation and varies between 180o and zero. Due to the dynamic nature of the earth’s interior, due to the changing position of the magnetic material in the Earth, the magnetic field is constantly changing. Since, the Earth's magnetic pole is slowly moving around, the variation changes over time and therefore the date of any map showing variation is important, because if it is an old map, its variations will be incorrect. The pilots should always fly with the most up-to-date chart for flight safety reasons. If the chart is republished at frequent intervals, the variation should be comparatively recent as well.

content.question: The angular difference between the geographical meridian and the magnetic meridian running through the same position is named:
